===Vegetation=== [[File:CuritibaGeadaFrost.jpg|thumb|left|[[Frost]] in Curitiba.]] [[File:Estufa-Jardim-Botanico-Curitiba-out.JPG|thumb|Botanical gardens greenhouse in Curitiba]] Curitiba is located in the area of the Ombrophilous Mixed Forest (also known as [[Araucaria moist forests]]), a sub-type of the [[Atlantic Forest]]. In Curitiba it is possible to find steppes, forests and other formations. The local vegetation consists of remnants of the Paraná (or Brazilian) pine (''[[Araucaria angustifolia]]''), which resisted the efforts of settlers. The Paraná pines are in private and public areas and are protected from logging. The Municipal Secretariat of the Environment maintains a [[botanical garden]] and three [[greenhouse]]s that produce 150,000 native and exotic seedlings: 16,000 fruit trees, 260,000 flowers, foliage and underbrush specimens and the maintenance of another 350,000 seedlings.{{cite web |title= City of Curitiba, Brazil|publisher=Convention on Biological Diversity |accessdate=23 May 2008 |url=http://www.cbd.int/authorities/casestudy/curitiba.}} {{Dead link|date=May 2018}} Curitiba's green area itself matches the size of other large Brazilian cities. The vegetation of Curitiba encompasses a large population of purple and yellow ''ipês'' ([[tabebuia]]s), making a beautiful sight during flowering at winter's end. The yellow ipê is the city's most common tree.{{cite web |title=Livro mostra roteiros das árvores de Curitiba/Pr |publisher=Ambiente Brasil |language=Portuguese |accessdate=25 May 2005 |url=http://www.ambientebrasil.com.br/noticias/index.php3?action=ler&id=18883 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019045953/http://www.ambientebrasil.com.br/noticias/index.php3?action=ler&id=18883 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 October 2015 }} {{wide image|Barigui Panorama.JPG|1200px|Panoramic view of Barigui Park.}} ===Hydrography=== [[File:Rio iguaçu curitiba.jpg|thumb|Iguaçu River, running by the south region of the city.]] The [[drainage basin|catchment area]] of Curitiba consists of rivers and streams that cross the city in different directions, grouped in six river basins. The main rivers that form the city's [[Drainage basin|watershed]] are: Atuba River, Belém River, Barigüi River, Passaúna River, Ribeirão dos Padilhas and the [[Iguaçu River]], all with characteristics of [[dendritic drainage]]. Curitiba has been working since the 1970s on alternatives to minimize the negative impacts of [[wikt:urbanization|urbanization]] on rivers. An example is the construction of parks along the rivers with artificial lakes, which absorb and retain water for longer periods of time, minimizing floods. After many studies of local water flows, most rivers were found to be subject to a [[Canalized|canalization]] process. Other alternatives developed to minimize the negative effects of urbanization are the implementation of programs for environmental education, inspection and monitoring, elaboration and application of legislation and infrastructure works. ===Topography=== [[File:Curitiba vista serra do mar.jpg|thumb|left|The Mountain Range of the Sea, ''"Serra do Mar."'']] The city covers {{convert|432.17|km2|2|abbr=out}} on the First Plateau of Paraná. Curitiba has a [[topography]] of smooth, rounded hills, giving it a relatively regular shape. The city has an average altitude of {{convert|934.6|m|ft}} above sea level. The highest point is to the north at {{convert|1021|m|ft}}, and with lower altitudes at {{convert|864|m|ft}} to the south. Mountain ranges and sets of [[rocky]] hills surround parts of the city, including the ''Serra do Mar'', a hill range between the shore of the Atlantic Ocean and the First Plateau in Paraná.{{cn|date=May 2018}} ==Government== [[File:Palácio 29 de Março Curitiba Paraná Brasil.jpg|thumb|right|The Curitiba City Hall]] {{As of|2017}}, the mayor is Rafael Greca, who replaced Gustavo Fruet. The [[City Council]] of Curitiba has 38 councillors elected since 2004. Curitiba is divided into nine regional governments (equivalent to [[subprefecture]]), who manage the municipality's 75 districts. The ''Rua da Cidadania'' ("Street of Citizenship") is the symbol of administrative decentralization; it is a reference point and a meeting place. Several units are annexed to public transport terminals. Their nuclei offer services in the local, [[States of Brazil|state]] and [[Federal republic|federal]] areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.zoohara.com/travel-guide-curitiba-parana-state-vacations-government|title=Curitiba, Brazil Travel Guide - Government - Zoohara|website=Zoohara.com|accessdate=22 March 2017}} [[Jaime Lerner]] is perhaps Curitiba's best-known mayor. He has been mayor three times, the first time in the early 1970s. His leadership was crucial to some major changes in the city. Curitiba has built parks instead of canals to reduce flooding; used parks to make the city more liveable; pedestrianised the downtown area; invented and built Bus Rapid Transit (BRT), a bus system that works like a light rail system but is 10 times cheaper; and started a massive recycling scheme that included giving people bus tokens in return for waste.{{cite web|url=http://www.citiesforpeople.net/cities/curitiba.html|title=Sitemap - ダポキセチンで早漏改善！|website=Citiesforpeople.net|accessdate=22 March 2017}} [[Time magazine]] listed this former [[mayor]] among the world's most influential thinkers of 2010. In the days before free, direct elections, mayors were political appointees who were no more than pawns in the game of power politics and were subject to replacement at any time. For an idealistic young architect like Lerner, retaining the mayor's office was particularly precarious. Those holding the reins of power at the time were under the mistaken impression that Lerner's youth would make him easy to control. As it turned out, he was no [[wikt:milquetoast|milquetoast]], and subsequently set about enthusiastically pursuing reform.{{cite web|url=http://english.cw.com.tw/article.do?action=show&id=13718&offset=0|title=Former Curitiba Mayor Jaime Lerner|website=English.cw.com.tw|accessdate=9 December 2017}} ==Demographics== [[File:Cerimonia de bencao dos alimentos.jpg|thumb|left|Brazilians of [[Ukrainian Brazilian|Ukrainian]] descent celebrating Easter in Curitiba.]] {{multiple image | direction = vertical | align = right | width = 220 | footer = | image1 = Curitiba - Bosque do Papa - Casa de Colono Polones.jpg | caption1 = Old [[Polish Brazilian|Polish]] house at João Paulo II park ("Pope's Park"). | image2 = Curitiba Parque Tingui.jpg | caption2 = Ukrainian memorial at [[Tingui Park]]. | image3 = CuritibaPracaDoJapaoCerejeira.JPG | caption3 = Memorial of Japanese immigrants at Japan's Square. }} According to the [[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|2010 IBGE Census]], 1,678,965 people resided in the city of Curitiba.[http://www.censo2010.ibge.gov.br:80/dados_divulgados/index.php?uf=41 2010 IGBE Census] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502213333/http://www.censo2010.ibge.gov.br/dados_divulgados/index.php?uf=41 |date=2 May 2012 }} {{pt icon}} The census revealed 1,381,938 [[White Brazilian|White]] people (78.9%), 294,127 [[Pardo]] ([[Multiracial#Brazil|Multiracial]]) people (16.8%), 49,978 [[Afro-Brazilian|Black]] people (2.9%), 23,138 [[Asian Brazilian|Asian]] people (1.4%), 2,693 [[Indigenous peoples in Brazil|Amerindian]] people (0.2%).[http://www.censo2010.ibge.gov.br/painel/?nivel=mn 2010 IGBE Census] {{pt icon}} In 2010, Curitiba was Brazil's 8th most populous city.{{cite web|url=http://noticias.uol.com.br/cotidiano/2010/11/04/maiores-cidades-do-brasil-crescem-menos-do-que-resto-do-pais-aponta-censo.jhtm|title=Maiores cidades do Brasil crescem menos do que média nacional, aponta Censo - Notícias - Cotidiano|website=Noticias.uol.com.br|accessdate=22 March 2017}} In 2010, the city had 359,201 opposite-sex couples and 974 [[same-sex couple]]s. The population of Curitiba was 52.3% female and 47.7% male. As with most of [[Southern Brazil]]'s population, Curitiba is mostly inhabited by European descendents. The first Europeans to arrive were of [[Portuguese Brazilian|Portuguese]] origin, during the 17th century. They [[interracial marriage|intermarried]] with the [[Indigenous peoples in Brazil|native people]] and with the African [[slave]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.curitiba.pr.gov.br/pmc/curitiba/index.asp?noframe=sim&conteudo=imigra/index.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703141121/http://www.curitiba.pr.gov.br/pmc/curitiba/index.asp?noframe=sim&conteudo=imigra%2Findex.html |archivedate=3 July 2007 |title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=3 July 2007 |accessdate=16 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Up until the 19th century, the inhabitants of the city of Curitiba were natives and mixed-race, Portuguese and Spanish immigrants. In 1808 foreigners were granted the right to ownership of land, and in 1853 Parana became an independpent province, and these events resulted in a substantial number so of immigrants from Europe. The first non-Iberic (Portuguese and Spaniard) immigrants to come to the city were [[German Brazilian|German]].{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba.pr.gov.br/idioma/ingles/curitibano|title=The 'Curitibano|publisher=Prefeitura de Curitiba|accessdate=19 March 2013}} The Memorial of Polish Immigration was inaugurated on 13 December 1980, after the visit of [[Pope John Paul II]] in June. Its area is {{convert|46000|m2}} and was part of the former Candles plant. The seven wooden log houses are parts of this memorial area, as a memento of the Polish immigrants' struggles and faith. Objects like an old wagon, pipe of cabbage and a print of the [[Black Madonna of Częstochowa]] (patron saint of the [[Polish people]]), form parts of the memorial.{{cite web|url=http://www.parques-curitiba.com/bosque-papa-joao-paulo.htm|title=Polish Memorial of Curitiba|publisher=Parques-curitiba.com|date=|accessdate=7 March 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715044611/http://www.parques-curitiba.com/bosque-papa-joao-paulo.htm|archive-date=15 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The first group of Poles arrived in Curitiba around 1871. Curitiba has the biggest colony of Polish immigrants in Brazil. [[Italian Brazilian|Italian immigrants]] started arriving in Brazil in 1875 and in Curitiba in 1878, coming mainly from the [[Veneto]] and [[Trento]] regions of [[Northern Italy]]. They settled mostly in the ''Santa Felicidade'' neighborhood, still a centre of the Italian community.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba-parana.net/italianos.htm |title=Imigração e Cultura Italiana |publisher=Curitiba-parana.net |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011|language=Portuguese}} Nearly 20,000 [[Ukrainians of Brazil|Ukrainian]] immigrants settled there between 1895 and 1897, consisting mostly of peasants from [[Galicia (Central Europe)|Galicia]] who emigrated to Brazil to become farmers. Around 300,000 Ukrainian-Brazilians live in Paraná.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba-parana.net/parques/memorial-ucraniano.htm |title=Ukrainian memorial in the city of Curitiba |publisher=Curitiba-parana.net |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www3.pr.gov.br/e-parana/pg_etnias.php |title=Paraná Government (Ukrainian community in the State) |publisher=.pr.gov.br |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712140342/http://www3.pr.gov.br/e-parana/pg_etnias.php |archivedate=12 July 2010}} The State of Paraná has the largest [[Ukrainians of Brazil|Ukrainian community]] and [[Slavic people|Slavic community]].{{cite web|url=http://www.brasil.kiev.ua/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=45&layout=blog&Itemid=30&9856877558d17ec206d1a87e99fb1dce=3fab537243dff8dbaf45e8c8619a395b |title=Slavic community in Curitiba |publisher=Brasil.kiev.ua |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203110425/http://www.brasil.kiev.ua/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=45&layout=blog&Itemid=30&9856877558d17ec206d1a87e99fb1dce=3fab537243dff8dbaf45e8c8619a395b |archivedate=3 December 2013}} Curitiba has a Jewish community[http://www.jewishbrazil.com/englishsp.htm Jews of Brazil site] Source listing Curitiba as one of the important Jewish communities. [https://www.scribd.com/doc/101125/Beis-Moshiach-604 A Habad article] gives the number of 844 religious participating families there in the year 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishbrazil.com/englishsp.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-06-05 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815021641/http://www.jewishbrazil.com/englishsp.htm |archivedate=15 August 2007 |df=dmy }} that was originally established in the 1870s.[https://www.jstor.org/pss/3512913 Brazil's Jews during the Vargas Era and After] by [[Robert M. Levine]] 1968. This is a book about early Jewish settlers in Brazil Much of the early Jewish congregation has been assimilated.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OnweHjc-zx4C&pg=PA122&lpg=PA122&dq=curitiba+jews&source=web&ots=EkxvaoF1nc&sig=3j2vN6UY5bj0HCyFbREx5G4To94&hl=en |title=Digital edition of Levine's book |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} In 1937 with the rise of [[Nazi]] Germany, notable German Jewish academics migrated to Brazil, some settling in Curitiba.A research paper about the [http://www.escholarship.org/editions/view?docId=ft367nb2gm;brand=ucpress Jewish immigration to Brazil] during the second world war. Physicist [[César Lattes]] and former mayors [[Jaime Lerner]]{{cite web|url=http://www.heschel.org.il/eng/jgen |title=Jewish in Curitiba |publisher=Heschel.org.il |date=18 April 2007 |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017062111/http://www.heschel.org.il/eng/jgen |archivedate=17 October 2010}} and Saul Raiz were Jewish. A Holocaust memorial is present in the city. The [[Centro Israelita do Paraná|community centre]], a [[Jewish school]], a [[Chabad house]] (Beit Chabad),{{cite web|url=http://www.chabadcuritiba.com/ |title=Beit Chabad |publisher=Chabadcuritiba.com |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} a synagogue,[http://www.raoulwallenberg.net/?en/about/reports/report-activities-7-2003.1296.htm Israel Synagogue] in addition to the Hevra Kadisha Synagogue and the Habad Synagogue mentioned in the Chabad reference and two Jewish cemeteries are there,[http://www.jewishgen.org/Cemetery/southamerica/brazil.html Jewish Genealogy site] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080421011042/http://www.jewishgen.org/Cemetery/southamerica/brazil.html |date=21 April 2008 }} lists cemeteries. one of which was defiled in 2004.{{cite web |url=http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2004/brazil.htm |title=Stephen Roth Institute: Antisemitism And Racism |publisher=Tau.ac.il |date=28 August 2004 |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807221758/http://www.tau.ac.il/Anti-Semitism/asw2004/brazil.htm |archivedate=7 August 2007 |df=dmy-all }} [[Japanese-Brazilian|Japanese]] immigrants began arriving in 1915, with a larger contingent arriving in 1924. Curitiba received a significant Japanese influx. They settled mostly between Paraná and São Paulo state. The city has the second largest Japanese community in Brazil, behind only São Paulo, according to [[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]]. Although both cities have around the same proportion of Japanese descendants, other large cities in the countryside, such as Maringá and Londrina, have an even higher rate. Some estimates suggest that more than 40,000 Japanese-Brazilians live in Curitiba.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba-parana.net/japao.htm |title=Japan Square in Curitiba |publisher=Curitiba-parana.net |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} ==Economy== {{further|Economy of Brazil|Tourism in Brazil}} [[File:Brasil Telecom Panoramic Tower Curitiba Brasil.jpg|thumb|left|Oi Panoramic Tower.]] [[File:CuritibaTradeCenterSkyline.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Downtown Curitiba skyline.]] Since it was declared capital of the State of Paraná in 1853, the city has gone through several major urban planning projects to avoid uncontrolled growth and thus has become an international role model in dealing with issues including transportation and the environment.[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/brazil2014/destination/cities/city=35400/index.html Curitiba Economy – FIFA report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100505083751/http://www.fifa.com/worldcup/brazil2014/destination/cities/city%3D35400/index.html |date=5 May 2010 }} The city is Brazil's second largest car manufacturer. Its economy is based on industry, commerce and services. For that reason, Curitiba is considered by many investors to be the best location for investment in Brazil. The city receives more than two million tourists every year. Most arrive via [[Afonso Pena International Airport]], where almost 60,000 flights land annually.{{cite web|url=http://www.brasilprimedesign.com/eng/lernoticia.asp?cod=56 |title=Curitiba – Economic ranks |publisher=Brasilprimedesign.com |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708091133/http://www.brasilprimedesign.com/eng/lernoticia.asp?cod=56 |archivedate=8 July 2011}} According to IPEA data, the GDP in 2006 was 32 billion [[Brazilian real|reals]], without including agriculture and livestock (0.03%). Industry represented 34.13% and the commerce and service sectors 65.84%.{{cite web|url=http://www.ipardes.gov.br/cadernos/Montapdf.php?Municipio=80000&btOk=ok |title=GDP – Curitiba |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} Cidade Industrial de Curitiba, the industrial district, is home to many multinational industries, such as [[Nissan]], [[Renault]], [[Volkswagen]], [[Philip Morris International|Philip Morris]], [[Audi]], [[Volvo]], [[HSBC]], [[Siemens]], [[ExxonMobil]], [[Electrolux]] and [[Kraft Foods]], as well as many well-known national industries, such as [[Sadia]], O Boticário and Positivo Informática. Curitiba's infrastructure makes bus travel fast and convenient, effectively creating demand for bus use in the same way that the infrastructure of traditional cities creates demand for private motor vehicles. In July 2001, Curitiba became Brazil's first city to receive the prize "Pole of Information Technology", granted by ''InfoExame'' magazine. According to the magazine, the companies of "Technology and Information Technology" based in Curitiba in 2001 achieved {{USD|1.2 billion}} in revenues, representing a growth of 21% over the previous year.{{cite web |title=A capital do Paraná se destaca na área de TI e oferece oportunidades para profissionais do setor.|publisher=Revista TI|language=Portuguese|accessdate=11 October 2003 |url=http://www.timaster.com.br/revista/materias%5Cmain_materia.asp?codigo=648}} [[File:Shopping Estacao 1 Curitiba Brasil.jpg|thumb|right|Estação Mall.]] The city's 30-year economic growth rate is 7.1%, higher than the national average of 4.2%, and per capita income is 66% higher than the Brazilian average. Between 1975 and 1995, Curitiba's domestic product grew by some 75% more than the entire State of Paraná, and 48% more than Brazil as a whole. In 1994, tourism generated {{USD|280 million}}, 4% of the city's net income. Curitiba has municipal health, education and day care networks, neighborhood libraries shared by schools and citizens and Citizenship Streets, where buildings provide essential public services, sports and cultural facilities near transportation terminals. At the Open University, residents can take courses in subjects such as mechanics, hair styling and environmental protection for a small fee. Policies for job creation and income generation became part of the city's [[strategic planning]] in the 1990s, for the metropolitan area as well as the city.{{cite web|url=http://hopebuilding.pbworks.com/Brazilian-city-of-Curitiba-may-be-most-livable-city-in-the-world |title=Economy – City of Curitiba |publisher=Hopebuilding.pbworks.com |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} [[File:PacoDaLiberdadeCuritiba1.JPG|thumb|left|The "Paço Municipal" built in 1916.]] Since 1990, the Municipal Housing Fund has provided financial support to housing for lower income populations. After national housing finance collapsed in 1985, just as people from the countryside poured into Curitiba, the city's [[public housing]] program bought one of the few remaining large plots of land, "Novo Bairro" (New Neighborhood), as home for 50,000 families. While landowners built the houses themselves, each received a pair of trees and an hour's consultation with an architect to help them develop their plan. COHAB also built Technology Street, an avenue of 24 homes in the centre of Novo Bairro, each built using different construction techniques.{{cite web|url=http://hopebuilding.pbworks.com/Brazilian-city-of-Curitiba-may-be-most-livable-city-in-the-world |title=Housing Program Curitiba |publisher=Hopebuilding.pbworks.com |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} Seven massive shopping malls are found in Curitiba shopping: Mueller, Estação, Curitiba, Crystal, Palladium, Patio Batel and Park Barigüi. The [[Rua das Flores]] (Street of Flowers) is home to the majority of stores. The area is pedestrianized, with no cars around the centre. An essential element of Curitiba shopping is the Feira do Largo da Ordem, or Largo da Ordem Street Fair.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba.info/curitiba-shopping.html |title=Shopping in Curitiba, Brazil |publisher=Curitiba.info |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} In 2008, according to [[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]] Curitiba´s nominal [[GDP]] was {{BRL|45.7 billion}} (or about of {{USD|22.5 billion}}){{cite web|url=http://www.ibge.gov.br/home/estatistica/economia/pibmunicipios/2004_2008/ |title=Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística |publisher=IBGE |date= |accessdate=3 January 2013}} (with {{BRL|25,934}}, or {{USD|13,000}}, by nominal GDP per capita, about of {{USD|5,000}} more than Brazilian 2008 nominal GDP per capita), making it the fourth richest city in the country, after only [[São Paulo]], [[Rio de Janeiro]] and the capital [[Brasília]]. Curitiba is the 2nd Pole on Technological Innovation in Brazil, according to IPEA (Applied Economic Research Institute). The 2nd Brazil's Best City for Business and 5th [[South American]] Best City for Business, according to America Economia Magazine/2005 and 2006. The Best Destination for Business, according to [[Veja Magazine]] of 2007. The 3rd position among the Champions of Infrastructure, [[Exame (magazine)|Exame Magazine]] of 2006. The 2nd Best City to Work in [[Southern Brazil]], according to Você S.A. Magazine of 2005. The 49th Position, MasterCard Worldwide Centers of Commerce: Emerging Markets Index of 2008. One of the highlights according to the survey Offshoring Horizons performed by Watson Wyatt of 2007. One of the 10 global [[sustainability]] centres, according to [[Ethisphere Institute]] of 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.agencia.curitiba.pr.gov.br/publico/conteudo.aspx?codigo=82|title=Invest in Curitiba - Agência Curitiba S/A|website=Agencia.curitiba.pr.gov.br|accessdate=22 March 2017}} Curitiba is also home to the largest cancer hospital in the South of Brazil, [[Erasto Gaertner Hospital]].{{cite web|url=http://erastogaertner.com.br/pagina/historico|title= Hospital Erasto Gaertner, Historico Institucional|website=erastogaertner.com.br |accessdate=26 February 2018}} {{clear}} == Attractions== [[File:Curitiba Botanic Garden.jpg|thumb|left|[[Botanical Garden of Curitiba]].]] [[File:Bosque de Portugal, Curitiba.JPG|thumb|right|Portugal Park]] Attractions in the city include: *Municipal Market: Located near the city's central bus station, it houses numerous shops selling imported goods, organic products, and vegan food. The food court has a lot of Asian food, vegan food and organic meals. * Italian Woods: Hosts local celebrations.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba.world-guides.com/curitiba_attractions.html|title=Curitiba Tourist Attractions and Sightseeing|work=World Guides|publisher=TravelSmart|accessdate=19 March 2013}} * Wire Opera House: Built on the site of an abandoned quarry.{{cite web|url=http://curitibainenglish.com.br/current-affairs/the-wire-opera-house-curitibas-most-original-theatre/|title=The Wire Opera House: Curitiba’s Most Original Theatre|date=1 November 2010|publisher=Curitiba in English|accessdate=18 March 2013}} * Oscar Niemeyer Museum: Artists from Paraná and other parts of Brazil have their work represented in the museum. Three rooms in the Eye are dedicated exclusively to [[photography]].{{cite web|url=http://gobrazil.about.com/od/braziliancities/tp/Top-10-Curitiba-Attractions.htm|title=Curitiba Rocks the Brazilian Winter as a World Cup Host City|website=Gobrazil.about.com|accessdate=22 March 2017}} * Panoramic Tower: The 360-foot tall lookout tower allows travelers a 360° view of Curitiba and has a telephone museum on the ground floor. * Portugal Wood: Homage to the [[Portuguese-Brazilian]] bonds, this space is highlighted by a track following a small brook, where one can see drawn on tiles excerpts from famous Portuguese language poets, as well as a tribute to the great Portuguese navigators and their discoveries. Families are often seen picnicking on the grounds. * Curitiba International Ecological Marathon: The Maratona Ecológica Internacional de Curitiba ("Curitiba International Ecological [[marathon]]") is held in November and is known as the hardest in Brazil,{{cite web |title=Maratona Ecológica de Curitiba – Ladeiras e incentivos do povo curitibano|publisher=Copacabana Runners|language=Portuguese|accessdate=7 August 2008 |url=http://www.copacabanarunners.net/maracur.html}} because it happens in the end of the year in the summer heat, and because of the hilly course. * Tourism Line: The ''Linha Tourismo'' bus stops at key tourist attractions across the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba.world-guides.com/curitiba_travel.html|title=Getting Around, Curitiba Travel, Transport and Car Rental|work=World Guides|publisher=TravelSmart|accessdate=19 March 2013}} ==Education== More than 183 universities operate in the state of Paraná.{{cite web|url=http://www.seruniversitario.com.br|title=Ser Universitário - Tudo sobre o mundo universitário e estudantil!|website=Seruniversitario.com|accessdate=22 March 2017}} [[File:Universidade Federal do Parana 4 Curitiba Parana.jpg|thumb|right|[[Federal University of Paraná]] was the first university opened in Brazil.[http://www.superclickmonografias.com/monografiaufprmonografiaprontaufpr.html UFPR – History]{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924045847/http://www.superclickmonografias.com/monografiaufprmonografiaprontaufpr.html |date=24 September 2008 }}]] [[File:CPM 1.jpg|thumb|right|Military School of Curitiba.]] ===Tertiary educational institutions=== * [[Universidade Federal do Paraná]] (UFPR) – Federal University of Paraná – This federal university is the largest of Paraná, with more than 35.000 students. The first university of Brazil; * [[Universidade Tecnológica Federal do Paraná]] (UTFPR) – Federal Technologic University of Parana is the first university of technology from Brazil; * [[Paraná Federal Institute of Education, Science and Technology|Instituto Federal de Educação, Ciência e Tecnologia do Paraná]] - Paraná Federal Institute of Education, Science and Technology; * [[Universidade Positivo]] (UP) - ''Positivo University'', private institution; * [[Universidade Estadual do Paraná]] (UNESPAR) - State University of Paraná, which includes EMBAP (Paraná School of Fine Arts); * [[Pontifícia Universidade Católica do Paraná]] (PUCPR) – Pontifical Catholic University of Parana - A major private university; * ESIC Business and Marketing School – International Website [http://www.esic.es/ ESIC] * [[Centro Universitário Curitiba]] (UNICURITIBA) - University Center Curitiba, old Law School of Curitiba.{{cite web|url=http://www.unicuritiba.edu.br/ |title=Unicuritiba |publisher=Unicuritiba |date= |accessdate=30 November 2013}} * [[Centro Universitário Internacional]] (UNINTER) * [[Fundação de Estudos Sociais do Paraná]] (FESPPR) - The First Economy Graduation in Paraná, since 1938 ===Educational system=== In the 1990s, the city started a project called ''Faróis do Saber'' ("Lighthouses of Knowledge"). These [[lighthouse]]s are free educational centres that include [[library|libraries]], Internet access and other cultural resources. Libraries work with municipal schools, offering a collection of approximately 5000 books, and provide cultural reference and leisure.{{cite web|title=CURITIBA, UNA CITTÀ DA FANTASCIENZA |publisher=Eco Fantascienza |language=Italian |accessdate=18 October 2008 |url=http://www.ecofantascienza.it/articoli/curitiba.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080501143512/http://www.ecofantascienza.it/articoli/curitiba.html |archivedate=1 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} Among Brazilian capitals, Curitiba has the highest literacy rate,{{cite web |title=Só 1% das cidades está livre de analfabetismo|publisher=O Estado de S. Paulo |language=Portuguese|accessdate=23 June 2007 |url=http://www.estado.com.br/editorias/2007/06/20/ger-1.93.7.20070620.3.1.xml}} and ranks number 1 in education among the Brazilian capitals.{{cite web |title=Índice da Educação Básica|publisher=Jornal da Globo|language=Portuguese|accessdate=28 April 2007 |url=http://jg.globo.com/JGlobo/0,19125,VTJ0-2742-20070426-278406,00.html}} ==Urban planning== [[File:Rua 24 horas 2 Curitiba Basil.jpg|thumb|180px|left|Entrance of [[Rua 24 Horas|24 Hours Street]].]] Curitiba has a planned transportation system, which includes lanes on major streets devoted to a [[bus rapid transit]] system. The buses are split into three sections ([[Bi-articulated bus|bi-articulated]]) and stop at designated elevated tubes, complete with access for disabled riders. Buses charge one price regardless of distance.Jonas Rabinovitch and Josef Leitman, "Urban Planning in Curitiba", ''Scientific American'', vol. 274, no. 3 (March 1996), pp. 46–53 The city preserves and cares for its green areas, boasting {{convert|51.5|m2|sqft}} of green space per inhabitant.{{cite web|url=http://noticias.terra.com.br/ciencia/interna/0,,OI1926962-EI299,00.html|title=Curitiba busca recuperação de biodiversidade local Terra – Ambiente |publisher=Noticias.terra.com.br |date= |accessdate=22 July 2009}} In the 1940s and 1950s, [[Alfred Agache (architect)|Alfred Agache]], cofounder of the [[French Society for Urban Studies]], was hired to produce the first city plan. It emphasised a star of boulevards, with public amenities downtown, an industrial district and sanitation. The plan was too expensive to complete.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba.pr.gov.br/Paginas/ENG/Default.aspx?idf=532&servico=40 |title=Prefeitura ENG |publisher=Curitiba.pr.gov.br |date= |accessdate=22 July 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} By the 1960s, Curitiba's population had reached 430,000. Some residents feared that the growth in population threatened to damage the character of the city. In 1964, Mayor Ivo Arzua solicited proposals for urban design. Architect [[Jaime Lerner]], who later became mayor, led a team from the [[Universidade Federal do Paraná]] that suggested strict controls on urban sprawl, reduced traffic in the downtown area, preservation of Curitiba's Historic Sector and a convenient and affordable public transit system.[http://www.mcachicago.org/massivechange/timelines/urban.pdf About Curitiba] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125170008/http://mcachicago.org/massivechange/timelines/urban.pdf |date=25 November 2010 }} This plan, known as the Curitiba Master Plan, was adopted in 1968. Lerner closed [[Rua XV de Novembro|XV de Novembro St.]] to vehicles, because it had high pedestrian traffic. The plan had a new road design to minimise traffic: the Trinary Road System. This used two one-way streets moving in opposite directions that surround a smaller, two-lane street where the express buses have an exclusive lane. Five of these roads form a star that converges on the city centre. Land farther from these roads is zoned for lower density development, to pull traffic away from the main roads. In a number of areas subject to floods, buildings were condemned and the land became parks.[http://www.pescacommosca.com.br/noticia/lernoticia.php?IdtNoticia=869 Parks of Curitiba and floods] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061012061522/http://www.pescacommosca.com.br/noticia/lernoticia.php?IdtNoticia=869 |date=12 October 2006 }} Today, Curitiba is considered one of the world's best examples of urban planning.Irazábal, Clara Elena (2002) ''Curitiba and Portland: Architecture, City Making, and Urban Governance in the Era of Globalization'', PhD Dissertation in Architecture, University of California, Berkeley, p.112 In June 1996, the chairman of the [[Habitat II]] summit of mayors and urban planners in [[Istanbul]] praised Curitiba as "the most innovative city in the country."{{cite web|url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?pid=S0104-44782001000100007&script=sci_arttext |title=Curitiba – urban plannig |doi=10.1590/S0104-44782001000100007 |publisher=Scielo.br |date=31 March 1993 |accessdate=7 March 2011}} [[File:Rua xv curitiba.jpg|thumb|right|180px|15 November Street.]] Curitiba was recently recommended by [[UNESCO]] as a model for the reconstruction of the cities of [[Afghanistan]].{{cite web |script-title=ja:クリチバもモデルに＝カブール復興計画に参加 |publisher=Nikkey Shimbun|language=Japanese |accessdate=21 October 2008 |url=http://www.nikkeyshimbun.com.br/020615-24brasil.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041103064150/http://www.nikkeyshimbun.com.br/020615-24brasil.html |archivedate=3 November 2004}} In the 1980s, the RIT ([[Rede Integrada de Transporte]], ''Integrated Transport Network'') was created.{{cite web|url=http://www.urbs.curitiba.pr.gov.br/PORTAL/historiadotransportecoletivo.php |title=RIT Curitiba – Trajetory |publisher=Urbs.curitiba.pr.gov.br |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} At the same time, the city began building the "Faróis de Saber" (''Lighthouses of Knowledge'') educational centres.{{cite web|url=http://www.cmc.pr.gov.br/ass_det.php?not=7004 |title=Social programs in the city |publisher=Cmc.pr.gov.br |date=16 May 2006 |accessdate=7 March 2011}} The city has more than {{convert|400|km2|0|abbr=out}} of public parks and forests.{{cite web|url=http://www.greenplanetmonitor.net/news/2012/12/curitiba-sustainable-city/|title=Curitiba - Sustainable City|last=Anil Mundra|date=27 December 2012|publisher=Green Planet Monitor|accessdate=19 March 2013}} In 2007, the city placed third in a list of "15 Green Cities" in the world, according to "[[Grist (magazine)|Grist]]" magazine, after [[Reykjavík]] in Iceland and [[Portland, Oregon]] in the United States. As a result, according to one survey, 99% of Curitibans are happy with their hometown.{{cite web |title=15 Green Cities|publisher=Grist|accessdate=10 July 2007 |url=http://www.grist.org/article/cities3}} Jaime Lerner suggests [[Urban Acupuncture|urban acupuncture]] as the future solution for contemporary urban issues; focusing on very narrow pressure points in cities, can create positive ripple effects. Urban "acupuncture" reclaims land for the public and emphasizes the importance of community development through small interventions in design of cities.[http://forum.davidson.edu/anthro16/space/urban-acupuncture/ Urban Acupuncture] - '' Understanding Space'' 2011 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425152838/http://forum.davidson.edu/anthro16/space/urban-acupuncture/ |date=25 April 2012 }} It emphasises pinpoint interventions that can be accomplished quickly to create a make an immediate impact.[http://www.brazilmax.com/news.cfm/tborigem/pl_south/id/10 Curitiba: Jaime Lerner’s Urban Acupuncture] - ''Bill Hinchberger, Brazilmax'' 2/2006 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111204151632/http://www.brazilmax.com/news.cfm/tborigem/pl_south/id/10 |date=4 December 2011 }} The "capacity building job line" was created to accelerate economic development. Key initiatives include the South-Circular bus line, which links the southern and eastern regions of town; Entrepreneurial "Sheds", business incubators designed to help small companies get established and prosper; and the Crafts Lycée, which trains people for [[profession]]s such as marketing and finance. Specifically, the goal is to provide jobs and income for the unemployed among 400,000 people living in 15 peripheral towns, and to structure and develop the region according to integrated planning principles. About 15,000 new jobs were generated by 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www3.iclei.org/localstrategies/summary/curitiba2.html|title=Curitiba a green city|website=3.iclei.org|accessdate=22 March 2017}} According to Jonas Rabinovitch, a United Nations senior adviser and former planner at the ''Curitiba Research and Urban Planning Institute'' (IPPUC), up to 8% of Curitiba's population still lived in [[favelas]] as of 2016.{{cite web|last1=Adler|first1=David|title=Story of cities #37: how radical ideas turned Curitiba into Brazil's 'green capital'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/may/06/story-of-cities-37-mayor-jaime-lerner-curitiba-brazil-green-capital-global-icon|website=The Guardian|accessdate=2 August 2017|date=6 May 2016|quote=Up to 8% of Curitiba still lives in favelas; it is not a socio-economic island within the Brazilian context.}} According to 2010 census data collected by [[Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics|IBGE]], 49.7 thousand homes in Curitiba form part of irregular settlements.{{cite web|title=9,3% dos curitibanos moram em favelas - Giro pelos Bairros|url=http://www.gazetadopovo.com.br/blogs/giro-pelos-bairros/93-dos-curitibanos-moram-em-favelas/|website=Giro pelos Bairros|publisher=Gazeta do Povo|accessdate=2 August 2017|language=pt-BR|date=6 September 2012|quote=Em Curitiba, há 49,7 mil domicílios nesta situação. Isso é equivalente a 163,3 mil pessoas. O crescimento populacional das favelas cresceu 12,4% entre 2000 e 2010, ritmo mais acelerado do que a população como um todo (10,3%).}} This is equivalent to 163.3 thousand people. The population growth of favelas was 12.4% between 2000 and 2010, higher than the population in general (10.3%). The transit service is used by more than 2 million people a day. Curitiba has more car owners per capita than anywhere else in Brazil. The population has doubled since 1974, yet auto traffic declined by 30%, and [[atmospheric pollution]] is the lowest in Brazil.{{cite web|url=http://www3.iclei.org/localstrategies/summary/curitiba2.html|title=Curitiba – low pollution|website=3.iclei.org|accessdate=22 March 2017}} ==Culture== [[File:Curitiba - Feira do Largo da Ordem - Grupo de Chorinho.JPG|thumb|left|Musicians in [[Feirinha do largo da ordem]].]] In January 1973 the Fundação Cultural de Curitiba was set up, with the aim of promoting culture. [[File:Opera de Arame Interior.jpg|thumb|left|[[Wire Opera House]].]] The Cultural Complex Solar do Barão features the Photography Museum, the Engravings Museum and the Posters Museu. The MuMA - Museu Metropolitano de Arte (Museum of Metropolitan Art) displays artists from the state of Paraná as well as renowned Brazilian [[painter]]s such as Pancetti, Guignard and [[Di Cavalcanti]] The Polish Immigrants Memorial, also known as The Pope's Woods, offers an enjoyable area surrounded by trees, which makes it a perfect choice for a stroll. The Pope himself blessed the first [[replica]] of the traditional Polish houses that beautifully make up the Bosque do Papa when he visited the city in 1980.{{cn|date=May 2018}} In 2003, Curitiba received the "[[American Capital of Culture]]" title, granted by the OAS ([[Organization of American States]]). [[File:Museu de Arte Contemporânea do Paraná (MAC).jpg|thumb|right|Museum of Contemporary Art of Paraná.]] ===Arts and entertainment=== Curitiba was Brazil's first city to have an [[IMAX]] movie theatre.{{cite web|url=http://www.shoppingpalladium.com.br/ |title=Palladium Shopping Center |publisher=Shoppingpalladium.com.br |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} Curitiba has many theaters. The largest and most important one is the Guaíra Theater.{{cite web|url=http://www.tguaira.pr.gov.br/ |title=Teatro Guaíra |publisher=Tguaira.pr.gov.br |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} Every year, in April, it hosts the Curitiba Theater Festival. ===Museums=== Brazilian architect [[Oscar Niemeyer]] designed the extravagant state museum of Curitiba. Its design includes a gravity-defying construction that was intended to look like a [[Araucaria angustifolia|Paraná Pine]], one of the city's symbols, but is widely interpreted by locals as an eye, which gave the Museum its nickname – ''Museu do Olho'', or Museum of the Eye. In keeping with Curitiba's history and culture of science, the museum offers many science exhibitions, including biennial exhibitions. The Curitiba museum includes the Oscar Niemeyer auditorium.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba.info/curitiba-history.html |title=Museums in the city |publisher=Curitiba.info |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} * Museu Paranaense (''"Paranaense Museum"'') – dedicated to arts and history; * [[Oscar Niemeyer Museum]] – the largest museum of South America,{{cite web |title=Museu Oscar Niemeyer|publisher=Descubra Curitiba|language=Portuguese|accessdate=17 January 2008 |url=http://www.descubracuritiba.com.br/?s=exposicao&ss=museu&id=584}} dedicated to plastic arts; * Museu de Arte Sacra (''"Religious Art Museum"'') – the focus is Christian art; * Museu do Expedicionário ("''Museum of the Expeditionary"'') – dedicated to Brazilian participation in World War II; * Museu de Arte Contemporânea (''"Museum of Contemporary Art"''); * Museu da Imagem e do Som (''"Image and Sound Museum"'') – about cinema and photography; * Museu Metropolitano de Arte de Curitiba (''"Metropolitan Museum of Art in Curitiba"'') – modern art; * Museu de História Natural (''"Natural History Museum"'') – [[biology]] and [[botany]]. * Museu do Holocausto (''"Holocaust Museum"'') {{cite web|url=http://www.museudoholocausto.org.br|title=Campanha Sobrevivente - Museu do Holocausto de Curitiba|website=Museudoholocausto.org.br|accessdate=22 March 2017}} ===Festivals=== Curitiba has yearly festivals related to arts, such as Curitiba Theatre Festival{{cite web|url=http://entretenimento.uol.com.br/ultnot/2011/03/28/20-edicao-do-festival-de-teatro-de-curitiba-comeca-nesta-terca-29.jhtm |title=Festival de Teatro de Curitiba chega a sua 20ª edição com mais de 400 peças - 28/03/2011 - Da Redação |publisher=Entretenimento.uol.com.br |date= |accessdate=3 January 2013}} and the Music Workshop of Curitiba.{{cite web|author=Do G1 PR |url=http://g1.globo.com/parana/noticia/2012/01/oficina-de-musica-de-curitiba-inicia-neste-domingo-com-musica-erudita.html |title=G1 - Oficina de Música de Curitiba inicia neste domingo com música erudita - notícias em Paraná |publisher=G1.globo.com |date=9 January 2012 |accessdate=3 January 2013}} Others celebrate immigrants festivals, such as the Grape Feast (''"Festa da Uva"''),{{cite web|url=http://www.bonde.com.br/?id_bonde=1-33--14-20090107 |title=51ª Festa da Uva de Curitiba - Gastronomia - Bonde. O seu portal |publisher=Bonde.com.br |date=6 January 1990 |accessdate=3 January 2013}} which is related to [[Italian Brazilian|Italian]] immigrants, and the four [[Matsuri]], related to [[Japanese Brazilian|Japanese]] immigrants. The four Matsuri set in Curitiba are: Imin Matsuri ([[Japanese language|Japanese]]: 移民祭り, "Immigration Festival") which celebrates the arrival of Japanese immigrants in Brazil,{{cite web|url=http://www.parana-online.com.br/editoria/almanaque/news/183378 |title=Governador prestigia Imin Matsuri, tradicional festa da colônia japonesa - Paraná-Online - Paranaense como você |publisher=Parana-online.com.br |date= |accessdate=3 January 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gazetadopovo.com.br/vidaecidadania/conteudo.phtml?id=778958 |title=Vida e Cidadania |publisher=Gazeta do Povo |date= |accessdate=3 January 2013}} Haru Matsuri ([[Japanese language|Japanese]]: 春祭り, "Spring Festival") which celebrates the end of winter and coming of spring,{{cite web|url=http://www.parana-online.com.br/editoria/almanaque/news/561323 |title=Haru Matsuri comemora chegada da primavera em Curitiba - Paraná-Online - Paranaense como você |publisher=Parana-online.com.br |date= |accessdate=3 January 2013}} Hana Matsuri{{cite web|author=Tadaima! Curitiba |url=http://www.tadaimacuritiba.com.br/evento-hana-matsuri-2011/ |title=Evento: Hana Matsuri 2011 |publisher=Tadaima! Curitiba |date=25 March 2011 |accessdate=3 January 2013}} ([[Japanese language|Japanese]]: 花祭り, "Flower Festival"), which celebrates the birth of [[Sakyamuni]],{{cite web|url=http://www.culturajaponesa.com.br/htm/hanamatsuri.html |title=Hanamatsuri |publisher=Culturajaponesa.com.br |date= |accessdate=3 January 2013}} and Seto Matsuri ("Seto Festival"), in honor of Cláudio Seto,{{cite web|title=Eventos: Seto Matsuri dias 06 e 07 de novembro|date=15 October 2010|language=Portuguese|publisher=Tadaima - Cultura Japonesa|author=Myrelle Silva|accessdate=24 January 2012|url=http://www.tadaimacuritiba.com.br/eventos-seto-matsuri-dias-06-e-07-de-novembro}} comic artist, precursor of the [[manga]] in Brazil and idealist of the first Matsuri in Curitiba. Curitiba also hold the famous Psycho Carnival,{{cite web|url=http://specialparana.com/psycho-carnival-zombie-walk-curitiba |title=Eventos: 2016 Psycho Carnival|date=February 2016|language=Portuguese}} a three-day festival that happens during the Brazilian Carnival, but devoted to psychobilly and rockabilly genres, attracting people from all over the world. In the same occasion the Zombie Walk also happens. The 2016 edition took more than 20.000 people to the streets.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazetadopovo.com.br/videos/zombie-walk-leva-20-mil-pessoas-ao-centro-de-curitiba/ |title=Eventos: 2016 Zombie Walk|date=February 2016|language=Portuguese}} ===UN Convention on Biodiversity=== On 20–31 March 2006 the Convention on [[biodiversity]] took place in Pinhais (a city near Curitiba), addressing items of the 1993 [[Convention on Biological Diversity]] adopted by 188 countries.{{cite web|url=http://www.cartamaior.com.br/templates/editoriaMostrar.cfm?editoria_id=24&alterarHomeAtual=1 |title=UN Convention on Biodiversity and Biosecurity |publisher=Cartamaior.com.br |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} ==Transportation== [[File:Bus Stops 2 curitiba brasil.jpg|thumb|''Estação Tubo Praça Osório'', one of the [[Estação Tubo|tube-shaped bus stops in Curitiba]].]] [[File:Taxis do Curitiba.jpg|thumb|The orange taxis of Curitiba.]] ===Public transport=== {{Main|Rede Integrada de Transporte}} Curitiba's public transportation consists entirely of buses. It opened the world's first [[bus rapid transit]] (BRT) system, [[Rede Integrada de Transporte]], in 1974.{{cite news|last=Schneider|first=Keith|title=Putting BRT in Car City, China|url=http://americancity.org/daily/entry/putting-brt-in-car-city-china|newspaper=Next American City|date=23 October 2012}} The popularity of Curitiba's BRT has effected a [[modal shift]] from automobile travel to bus travel. Based on 1991 traveler survey results, it was estimated that the introduction of the BRT had caused a reduction of about 27 million auto trips per year, annually saving about 27 million liters of fuel. In particular, 28 percent of BRT riders previously traveled by car. Compared to eight other Brazilian cities of its size, Curitiba uses about 30 percent less fuel per capita, resulting in one of the country's lowest rates of ambient air pollution. Some 1,100 buses make 12,500 trips every day, serving more than 1.3 million passengers, 50 times the number from 20 years ago. Eighty percent of travelers use the express or direct bus services. Curitibanos spend only about 10 percent of their income on travel, much below the national average.{{cite web|last=Goodman |first=Joseph |url=http://www.urbanhabitat.org/node/344 |title=Urban transport of Curitiba |publisher=Urbanhabitat.org |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011}} The city government has been planning to introduce an [[metro (rapid transit)|underground metro]] for a number of years and in 2014 announced opened tenders for a 35-year [[public private partnership]] contract to build and operate a {{convert|17.6|km|1|adj=on|abbr=off}}, 14-station north-south line. The cost is estimated at 4.62 billion reais.{{cite web|title= Curitiba re-launches metro concession tender|url=http://www.globalmasstransit.net/archive.php?id=16722|date=July 8, 2014}} ===Roads=== Moving around in a car can be difficult in and around the city centre because of the many one-way streets and frequent traffic jams. The Trinary Road System allows quick access to the city centre for drivers. Some avenues are spacious and laid out in a grid. Apart from some points around the city centre, Munhoz da Rocha Street and Batel Avenue, traffic jams are not severe.{{cite web|url=https://www.hagah.com.br/mapas |title=Roads in Curitiba |publisher=Hagah.com.br |date=21 February 2011 |accessdate=7 March 2011}} ===Air=== [[File:afonsopenaairport.jpg|thumb|Aerial view of [[Afonso Pena International Airport]].]] [[Afonso Pena International Airport]] is Curitiba's main airport. It is located in the nearby city of [[São José dos Pinhais]]. All commercial flights operate from this airport.[http://www.infraero.gov.br/usa/aero_prev_home.php?ai=221 Afonso Pena International Airport] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081020001130/http://www.infraero.gov.br/usa/aero_prev_home.php?ai=221 |date=20 October 2008 }} There is also the [[Bacacheri Airport]], a smaller general aviation facility. === Rail === Brazil's transportation and railway company, [[América Latina Logística|Rumo]], has its headquarters in Curitiba.{{Cite web|url=http://pt.all-logistica.com/all/web/default_eni.asp?idioma=1&conta=46|title=Rumo|website=pt.all-logistica.com|access-date=2017-05-12}} Serra Verde Express provides a tourist train through scenic country{{Citation|last=Jim McDaniel|title=Curitiba to Paranaguá by Train|date=2010-06-06|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=84KIjcrHYPE|accessdate=2017-05-12}} to [[Morretes]] and Paranaguá.{{Cite web|url=http://www.serraverdeexpress.com.br/site/en/trem/trem-de-luxo-curitiba/|title=Curitiba Luxury Train|last=|first=|date=|website=Serra Verde Express|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414085728/http://www.serraverdeexpress.com.br/site/en/trem/trem-de-luxo-curitiba/|archive-date=2016-04-14|dead-url=yes|access-date=}} ===Others=== The city has {{convert|100|km|0|abbr=on}} of bike routes, used by around 30 thousand bikers daily. City streets carry almost one million vehicles, of which 2,253 are orange Taxis. To service these vehicles, more than 355 petrol stations serve the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.brasilprimedesign.com/eng/lernoticia.asp?cod=56 |title=Curitiba |publisher=Brasilprimedesign.com |date= |accessdate=7 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708091133/http://www.brasilprimedesign.com/eng/lernoticia.asp?cod=56 |archivedate=8 July 2011}} ===Curitiba Public Transportation Statistics=== The average amount of time people spend commuting with public transit in Curitiba, for example to and from work, on a weekday is 72 min. 21% of public transit riders, ride for more than 2 hours every day. The average amount of time people wait at a stop or station for public transit is 17 min, while 33% of riders wait for over 20 minutes on average every day. The average distance people usually ride in a single trip with public transit is 7 km, while 12% travel for over 12 km in a single direction.{{cite web|url=https://moovitapp.com/insights/en/Moovit_Insights_Public_Transit_Index_Brazil_Curitiba-942|title=Curitiba Public Transportation Statistics|publisher=Global Public Transit Index by Moovit|accessdate=June 19, 2017}} [[File:CC-BY_icon.svg|50x50px]] Material was copied from this source, which is available under a [[creativecommons:by/4.0/|Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License]]. ==Sports== {{Main|2014 FIFA World Cup|Sports in Brazil}} [[File:Arenadabaixada2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Arena da Baixada]].]] Several association football teams play in Curitiba, [[Coritiba Foot Ball Club|Coritiba]] plays at [[Estádio Major Antônio Couto Pereira]], [[Clube Atlético Paranaense]] at [[Arena da Baixada|Estádio Joaquim Américo Guimarães]]. Both Coritiba and Atlético Paranaense have won [[Campeonato Brasileiro Série A]], in 1985 and 2001, respectively. Estádio Joaquim Américo Guimarães was one of the 12 stadiums to host games of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] held in Brazil. The stadium [[Vila Capanema]] have hosted the [[1950 FIFA World Cup]] which still is home to Paraná Clube.{{cite web|url=http://www.curitiba2014.com |title=Curitiba | FIFA World Cup 2014 |publisher=Curitiba2014.com |date= |accessdate=22 July 2009}} Clube Atlético Paranaense (Brazilian champion of 2001). Arena da Baixada is one of the three privately owned stadiums of the 2014 FIFA World Cup. The other two are [[Beira-Rio]] stadium, in [[Porto Alegre]] and [[Arena Itaquera]], in [[São Paulo]]. Arena da Baixada is considered one of the most modern stadiums in Brazil. This is the lowest budget of all venues of the 2014 FIFA World Cup. Most of the original stadium was preserved, and just an expansion is planned; today's capacity is 25,000, which should be increasead to about 42,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.aboutcuritiba.com/worldcup/stadium/|title=Arena da Baixada - Curitiba|website=Aboutcuritiba.com|accessdate=9 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819101214/http://www.aboutcuritiba.com/worldcup/stadium/|archive-date=19 August 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The [[Autódromo Internacional de Curitiba]] (Curitiba International Raceway) is located in nearby [[Pinhais]]. Curitiba has also one of the main [[rugby union]] clubs in Brazil, [[Curitiba Rugby Clube]], national champions in 2014. {{wide image|Panoramica CAP x SEP.JPG|700px|Panorama of inner [[Estádio Joaquim Américo Guimarães]] during a game between [[Sociedade Esportiva Palmeiras]] and [[Clube Atlético Paranaense]].}} ==Neighborhoods== [[File:Divisao administrativa Curitiba.svg|thumb|180px|Map of Curitiba, with the neighborhoods and boroughs.]] :''See also: {{illm|List of bairros of Curitiba|pt|Lista de bairros de Curitiba}}'' ''Bairros'' (neighborhoods) of Curitiba define the city's geographical divisions. Administrative powers are not delegated to neighborhoods, although neighborhood associations work to improve their communities. Curitiba is divided into 9 regional governments (boroughs) covering the 75 neighborhoods. Most districts of Curitiba were born of colonial groups formed by families of European immigrants in the second half of the nineteenth century. The centro (downtown or central business district), was where the city was founded, is the most bustling area, which concentrates most of the financial institutions of Curitiba.{{citation {{Infobox university |name= Department of Digital Humanities,
King's College London |parent= [[King's College London]] |image_name= KCL embankment facade.jpg |image_size= 310px |logo = King's College London Digital Humanities.png |logo_size= 150px |established= 1991 |type= |head_label= Head of Department |head= Professor Tobias Blanke |address= Strand Campus, [[London]], WC2B 5RL |city= [[London]] |country= [[UK]] |website= [http://www.kcl.ac.uk/artshums/depts/ddh/index.aspx Department of Digital Humanities] }} The '''Department of Digital Humanities''' ('''DDH''') (formerly '''Centre for Computing in the Humanities''') is an academic department and research centre in the [[King's College London Faculty of Arts and Humanities|Faculty of Arts & Humanities]] at [[King's College London]]. DDH counts amongst the "most visible"{{Cite journal| volume = 57| issue = 2| last = Caraco| first = Benjamin| title = Les digital humanities et les bibliothèques | journal = Le [[Bulletin des bibliothèques de France|Bulletin des Bibliothèques de France]]| accessdate = 12 April 2012| date = 1 January 2012| url = http://bbf.enssib.fr/consulter/bbf-2012-02-0069-002#appelnote-11}} digital humanities centres worldwide, with particular expertise in XML technologies (including [[Text Encoding Initiative|TEI]]), structured data and [[prosopography]], mapping and GIS, and user interface innovation. The primary objective of the Department is to foster awareness, understanding and skill in the scholarly applications of computing. It operates in three main areas: as a department with responsibility for its own academic programme; as a research centre promoting the appropriate application of computing in humanities research; and as a unit providing collegial support to its sister departments in the Faculty of Arts and Humanities. The Centre for Computing in the Humanities was established by Professor Harold Short in 1991, and changed its name in 2011. Professor Tobias Blanke, is currently Head of Department. ==See also== *[[King's College London]] *[[Digital Humanities]] *[[Humanistic informatics]] *[[Digital Classicist]] *[[Humanist (electronic seminar)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.kcl.ac.uk/artshums/depts/ddh/index.aspx Department of Digital Humanities Homepage] * [https://twitter.com/kingsdh Department of Digital Humanities] on Twitter * [http://www.facebook.com/kcl.ddh Department of Digital Humanities] on Facebook * [http://www.kcl.ac.uk/artshums/depts/ddh/people/index.aspx Staff Members] {{King's College London}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Digital Humanities, Department of}} [[Category:King's College London]] [[Category:Digital Humanities Centers]] {{UK-university-stub}}

{{more footnotes|date=April 2013}} '''Far East prisoners of war''' is a term used in the [[United Kingdom]] to describe former [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] [[prisoners of war]] held in the [[Far East]] during the [[Second World War]]. The term is also used as the [[initialism]] '''FEPOW''' (spelled out when said, not pronounced as a word), or as the [[abbreviation]] '''Far East POWs'''.
Its adoption by various independent voluntary organisations providing support to this specific community of former POWs is an implicit{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} indictment of the perceived lack of UK government support for this community, criticism partly deflected by a UK government compensation scheme introduced in 2000. [[Image:Portrait of "Dusty" Rhodes by Ashley George Old.jpg|right|thumb|220px|Portrait of FEPOW "Dusty" Rhodes. A three-minute sketch by [[Ashley George Old]] painted in Thailand in 1944.]]
== Compensation scheme ==
Since 2000, following a campaign led by the [[Royal British Legion]], former Far East POWs are eligible for UK Government compensation for their suffering in POW and internment camps operated by the Japanese during the War.
Compensation may be payable to any member of all British Groups imprisoned by the Japanese in the Second World War. It is therefore available to British civilians and [[British Merchant Navy|merchant seamen]] as well as members of British and Commonwealth forces. An amendment of the scheme in 2002 extended compensation to former [[Gurkha|Gurkha soldiers]].
An application may be made by either a former POW or their family or [[Estate (law)|estate]]. A successful FEPOW applicant is entitled to an ''[[ex gratia]]'' payment of £10,000. The scheme is currently administered by the [[Veterans Agency]].
== Clubs and organisations == [[File:The Far East Prisoners of War Memorial Building, National Memorial Arboretum - geograph.org.uk - 821086.jpg|thumb|left|The Far East Prisoners of War Memorial Building, [[National Memorial Arboretum]]]] The National Federation of Far East Prisoner of War Clubs and Associations (NFFCA) acts as an umbrella organisation for over 60 autonomous FEPOW Clubs and Associations in the UK.
The [http://www.fepow-community.org.uk FEPOW Community] has been set up to research loved ones who suffered under Japanese captivity during World War II. It does incorporate a free group, with its members helping each other in research. The Roll-of-Honour ([http://www.roll-of-honour.org.uk Roll of Honour]) has every death of service personnel and civilians mentioned in the site, most having a page of their own. The Far Eastern Heroes ([http://www.far-eastern-heroes.org.uk Far Eastern Heroes]) covers stories from the FEPOWs themselves, with a special page which promotes [http://www.fepow-day.org FEPOW Day] as 15 August, the day Japan surrendered.
Children and Families of the Far East Prisoners of War (COFEPOW) was founded in 1997 by Carol Cooper in [[Norfolk]] after a chance reading of a newspaper article about the discovery of a diary of a soldier who had died working on the [[Burma Railway]]. It emerged that the soldier was her father. In 1999 it became a registered charity. Today it comprises a membership of children and siblings of those who died as POWs and campaigns to raise awareness, raises funds for the creation of memorials both in the UK and the Far East, and offers resources for research.
In 2005, it established the Far East Prisoners of War Memorial Building at the [[National Memorial Arboretum]] in [[Staffordshire]], England. Within the building an exhibition tells the story of those captured by the Japanese during the Second World War. In the same area of the Arboretum are memorials for those prisoners of war who suffered and died building the Burma and [[Sumatra Railway]]s.
See Inside and explore the Museum [https://goo.gl/maps/YXajps3kVhP2 here]
== FEPOW War Artists == [[File:Bridge over the River Kwai Art.IWMARTLD6035.jpg|thumb|Bridge over the River Kwai by [[Leo Rawlings]]; four prisoners-of-war carry a large log across the [[Khwae Noi River|River Kwai]], waist deep in water]] Life in the POW camps was recorded at great risk to themselves by artists such as [[Jack Bridger Chalker]], [[Philip Meninsky]], [[Ashley George Old]] and [[Ronald Searle]]. Human hair was often used for brushes, plant juices and blood for paint, and toilet paper as the "canvas". Some of their works were used as evidence in the trials of Japanese war criminals.
The [[Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine]] undertook a study of British Far East POW medical art subsequent to a FEPOW oral history.<ref>http://www.captivememories.org.uk</ref>
== FEPOW Memorial Church == [[File:Wymondham Catholic Church and FEPOW memorial - geograph.org.uk - 1290555.jpg|thumb|Wymondham Catholic Church and FEPOW memorial]] Our Lady & St Thomas of Canterbury in [[Wymondham]], [[Norfolk]], England was completed in 1952 on the initiative of Father Malcolm Cowin - former Roman Catholic [[Chaplain]] to the [[2nd Cambridgeshire Regiment]] and who himself had spent 3½ years in Japanese POW camps. The site and a fund to build the church had been provided by Irish labours and [[USAAF]] personnel in the area. While a prisoner he helped construct three chapels in different camps and determined that on his return to the UK he would build a church in memory of those who died in Japanese POW and internment camps.
It serves as a parish church for the local Roman Catholic community as well as a focal point for the wider FEPOW community. There is a FEPOW shrine and an annual FEPOW memorial service held on the nearest Sunday to 14 May the anniversary of the relief of Rangoon.
==See also== * [[Burma Railway]] * [[Hellship]]s * [[King Rat (1962 novel)]] * [[Kra Isthmus Railway]] * [[Sumatra Railway]] * [[Civil Resettlement Units]]

{{Infobox journal | title = Film Quarterly | editor = | discipline = | abbreviation = Film Q. | publisher = [[University of California Press]] | country = [[United States]] | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1945–present | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://fq.ucpress.edu/ | link1 = http://fq.ucpress.edu/ | link1-name = Online archive | link2 = | link2-name = | cover =Cover of 70.2.jpg | former_names = Hollywood Quarterly
The Quarterly of Film Radio and Television | ISSN = 0015-1386 | eISSN = | OCLC = 1569205 | LCCN = a45005270 | JSTOR = 00151386 }} '''''Film Quarterly''''', a journal devoted to the study of film, television, and visual media, is published by [[University of California Press]]. It publishes scholarly analyses of international and Hollywood cinema as well as independent film, including documentary and animation. The journal also revisits film classics; examines television and digital and online media; reports from international film festivals; reviews recent academic publications; and on occasion addresses installations, video games and emergent technologies. It welcomes established scholars as well as emergent voices that bring new perspectives to bear on visual representation as rooted in issues of diversity, race, lived experience, gender, sexuality, and transnational histories. ''Film Quarterly'' brings timely critical and intersectional approaches to criticism and analyses of visual culture. Since 2013, it has been edited by [[B. Ruby Rich]], with Regina Longo as associate editor. In 2015, ''Film Quarterly'' began to receive funding from the [[Ford Foundation|Ford Foundation’s]] JustFilms initiative to “support the journal’s work in advancing criticism, analysis, and reporting with particular attention to social justice documentary and the interrogation of cinema practices across genres and platforms.”{{Cite web|url=http://content.ucpress.edu/pr/FQ_Ford_Press_Release_Sept.pdf|title=UC Press Release. September 30, 2015.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} == History == ''Film Quarterly'' was first published in 1945 as ''Hollywood Quarterly'', was renamed ''The Quarterly of Film, Radio, and Television'' in 1951, and has operated under its current title since 1958. === ''Hollywood Quarterly'' (1945–1951) === According to former ''Film Quarterly'' editorial board member Brian Henderson, “''Hollywood Quarterly'' was launched in 1945 as a joint venture of the Hollywood Writers Mobilization and the University of California Press. The association began as a wartime collaboration between educators and media workers in response to social needs occasioned by the war.”{{Cite book|url=http://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=ft5h4nb36j;brand=ucpress|title=Film Quarterly: Forty Years, a Selection.|last=Henderson, Brian, Ann Martin, and Lee Amazonas|first=|publisher=University of California Press.|year=1999|isbn=|location=Berkeley|pages=|via=}} Notable members of its first editorial board were playwright and screenwriter John Howard Lawson, psychologist Franklin Fearing, and writer-director Abraham Polonsky. === ''Quarterly of Film, Radio, and Television'' (1951–1958) === After allegations in a [[House Un-American Activities Committee|House of Un-American Activities]] Committee hearing that ''Hollywood Quarterly'' had communist leanings, in 1951, the journal changed its name to ''Quarterly of Film, Radio, and Television''. This name change inaugurated the journal’s clear divorce from the Hollywood industry with which it had partnered for several years. The journal’s turn towards “politically safe” work in the following years led to editorial discord and instability until August Frugé, then-director of UC Press, changed the direction of the journal. Frugé drew inspiration from the European film journals ''[[Sight & Sound|Sight and Sound]]'' and ''[[Cahiers du cinéma]]'', noting in his book that, "there was no American review comparable to these two, intellectual but not academic and devoted to film as art and not as communication. By accident we found ourselves with the means to publish one—if we chose and if we knew how."{{Cite book|url=http://www.ucpress.edu/book.php?isbn=9780520084261|title=A Skeptic Among Scholars: August Frugé on University Publishing.|last=Frugé|first=August|publisher=University of California Press|year=1993|isbn=|location=Berkeley|pages=|via=}} === ''Film Quarterly'' (1958- ) === Under the editorial guidance and visionary leadership of [[Ernest Callenbach]], the journal rebranded itself to bridge film criticism and scholarship, and was renamed ''Film Quarterly'' in Fall 1958. Its initial advisory board was composed of, among others, film scholar Andries Deinum; [[Gavin Lambert]], a former editor of ''Sight and Sound'' who was then a screenwriter in Hollywood; Albert Johnson, a Bay Area-based film programmer and critic; and [[Colin Young (film educator)|Colin Young]], who taught film at UCLA and later became the first director of the British [[National Film and Television School]]. Ernest Callenbach remained ''Film Quarterly''’s editor until the Fall 1991 issue; he had overseen the production of 133 issues by the end of his appointment. Ann Martin, who had worked as an editor at ''American Film'' and ''The New Yorker'', and on various film and video productions, served as the editor of ''Film Quarterly'' during 1991–2006. Rob White, who had edited the British Film Institute’s BFI Classics series, was in charge during 2006–2012. [[David Sterritt]] took over as guest editor for volume 66 in 2012–13. Immediately following its 40th anniversary, the University of California Press published a ''Film Quarterly'' anthology of its groundbreaking essays, co-edited by Brian Henderson and then-editor Ann Martin. Editorial board members Leo Baudry, [[Ernest Callenbach]], Albert Johnson, [[Marsha Kinder]], and [[Linda Williams (film scholar)|Linda Williams]] all participated in the conceptualization of the volume. In 2002, Ann Martin and Eric Smoodin (who was then the Film, Media, and Philosophy Acquisitions Editor at UC Press) co-edited a volume of highlights from the journal’s ''Hollywood Quarterly (''1945–1951) years. In 2013, film critic and historian B. Ruby Rich took over as editor for the journal. Rich's editorial vision has particularly emphasized work that engages with fresh approaches to film in a shifting digital media environment and a broadened view of cultural and critical approaches for both historical and contemporary work. ''Film Quarterly'' has emphasized the shifting forms and meanings the moving image has taken in the digital age and worked to expand its views of the field and the writers included in its pages. Special dossiers have focused on [[Joshua Oppenheimer]]’s ground-breaking ''[[The Act of Killing]]'', the cinema of [[Richard Linklater]], the significance of Brazilian documentarian [[Eduardo Coutinho|Edouardo Coutinho]], and the legacy of [[Chantal Akerman]]. Cover stories have focused on such films as [[Melvin Van Peebles|Melvin Van Peebles']] [[Watermelon Man (film)|''The Watermelon Man'']], [[Louis Massiah|Louis Massiah's]] ''[http://fq.ucpress.edu/content/68/4/8 The Bombing of Osage Avenue]'' and [[Jill Soloway]]'s ''[[Transparent (TV series)|Transparent]].'' ''Film Quarterly'' aims to widens the scope of voices published in its pages, creates a shared discourse for divergent platforms, and broadens the canon beyond traditional auteurism. == Pauline Kael’s Involvement == For a brief time in the 1950s, Pauline Kael was considered for the role of editor. She was then a programmer at the Cinema Guild, a repertory movie house in Berkeley, CA. Frugé and Kael did not share the same vision so the position was subsequently offered to Callenbach instead. Beginning in 1961, a regular feature, "Films of the Quarter," appeared in which a group of well-known film critics—[[Dwight Macdonald]], [[Stanley Kauffmann]], [[Pauline Kael]], [[Jonas Mekas]], and [[Gavin Lambert]]—discussed what they viewed as the best films of the prior three months. In the Spring 1963 issue, Pauline Kael famously attacked [[Andrew Sarris]]’ [[auteur theory]] in her landmark article, "Circles and Squares." In the Summer 1963 issue, Sarris responded to Kael’s critique with his own article, "The Auteur Theory and the Perils of Pauline." Kael included many of her articles, film reviews, and other material published in ''FQ'' during 1961–65 in her first book, ''[[I Lost It at the Movies]]'' (1965). == Notable contributors == {{Div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[André Bazin]] * [[André Bazin]] * [[David Bordwell]] * [[Noël Carroll]] * [[Manthia Diawara]] * [[Richard Dyer]] * [[Umberto Eco]] * [[Miriam Hansen]] * [[Pauline Kael]] * [[Laura Mulvey]] * [[Bill Nichols]] * [[B. Ruby Rich]] * [[Jonathan Rosenbaum]] * [[Andrew Sarris]] * [[Paul Schrader]] * [[Parker Tyler]] * [[Linda Williams (film scholar)|Linda Williams]] {{Div col end}} ==See also== * [[List of film periodicals]] == Further reading == * Frugé, August. 1993. ''A Skeptic Among Scholars: August Frugé on University Publishing''. Berkeley: University of California Press. * Henderson, Brian, Ann Martin, and Lee Amazonas. 1999. ''Film Quarterly: Forty Years, a Selection''. Berkeley: University of California Press. * Smoodin, Eric Loren, and Ann Martin. 2002. ''Hollywood Quarterly: Film Culture in Postwar America, 1945–1957''. Berkeley: University of California ==External links== * [http://fq.ucpress.edu/ Website (UC Press)] * [http://www.filmquarterly.org/ Journal Website] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Publications established in 1945]] [[Category:Film studies journals]] [[Category:Television studies journals]] [[Category:Media studies journals]] [[Category:University of California Press academic journals]]
